definitions.definition: Belonging to us , excluding the person(s) being addressed ( exclusive our ) .
examples: Sorry, you're not invited to our party.

definitions.definition: Belonging to us , including the person(s) being addressed ( inclusive our ) .
examples: We must try to save our marriage for the sake of our children.

definitions.definition: Of, from, or belonging to any entity that the speaker is a part of or identifies with, such as place of employment or education, nation , region , language , etc.
examples: Our safety record at ABC Widgets is very good.
In English, our nouns do not generally have gender.
As we get older, our reactions get slower.
How are we all tonight? Have we got our happy faces on?

definitions.definition: Belonging to an individual being addressed; used especially of a person in the speaker's care, or to whom advice or instruction is being given.
examples: How are we feeling this morning, Mrs Miggins? Have we taken our tablets yet?
You've been spending all your money boozing when you have a wife and family to support. I think we need to get our priorities straight.

definitions.definition: Belonging to a third person, especially someone in the speaker's care.
examples: "I've just been to see Mrs Miggins." — "And how is she?" — "Not too good today. We've had a little problem with our tummy."

definitions.definition: Used to imply connection between the speaker's experiences or activities and a group of listeners .
examples: Hey guys, in this video I'll show you how I make my upside-down sponge cake. First, let's get our ingredients weighed out.

definitions.definition: Used before a person's name to indicate that the person is in one's family, or is a very close friend.
examples: I'm going to see our Terry for tea.

main_definition: Belonging to us , excluding the person(s) being addressed ( exclusive our ) .
secondary_definitions: Belonging to us , including the person(s) being addressed ( inclusive our ) .
Of, from, or belonging to any entity that the speaker is a part of or identifies with, such as place of employment or education, nation , region , language , etc.
( colloquial ) Belonging to everyone being addressed.
( colloquial , may seem patronising ) Belonging to an individual being addressed; used especially of a person in the speaker's care, or to whom advice or instruction is being given.
( colloquial , uncommon ) Belonging to a third person, especially someone in the speaker's care.
( colloquial ) Used to imply connection between the speaker's experiences or activities and a group of listeners .
( Northern England , Scotland ) Used before a person's name to indicate that the person is in one's family, or is a very close friend.
